text.p: The following are the stories reported in Lithuanian newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- If a draft law on diplomatic passports is approved, dozens of officials who have nothing to do with diplomatic work will have the right to enjoy the privileges provided to the owners of such passports.

- Stanislovas Bushkevichius, a member of parliament, distributed a floppy disc with secret information to journalists. The disc belonged to a staff member of the country's security department, Juras Abromavichius, who was killed in a car explosion in January. Bushkevichius alleges that obstacles are being made in the investigation of the case.
- The board of Hermis bank has decided to buy shares worth five percent of its share capital and to sell them later.
- The Lithuanian government has decided to boost the share capital of Butinges Oil terminal to 260 million litas from 71.3 million litas.
- Energy officials will propose to the government a 40 percent increase in heating prices and a 25 percent rise in electricity prices in May or June.
- JP Morgan was chosen to be lead manager for the country's $200 million Eurobond issue.
- Swedish telecoms group Ericsson does not intend to participate in the privatisation of Lithuania's telecom.
- The Lithuanian government says it will not conscript more than 6,000 young people to the army this year.
- A Lithuanian delegation will meet heads of U.S. group Amoco in Washington. The foreign ministry would not explain the purpose of the meeting.

- Lithuanian President Algirdas Brazaukas says he does not intend to replace the head of the security department, Jurgis Jurgelis. After meeting Jurgelis to discuss the work of the organisation and its prospects for the future, the president said he was satisfied with the agency.
